header.title: The Scroll of Set: Issue Number 35 (July 1978) - 'The Third Year' and Related Articles

central_thesis: The document primarily serves as an internal report on the Temple of Set's third year of operation, detailing significant internal challenges, leadership disputes, and schisms, while reaffirming the organization's unique philosophical foundations (Xeper, Set) and its structured approach to supporting individual Setian development. It emphasizes the resilience of the Temple's design against ego-driven conflicts and outlines future initiatives to strengthen its operative system.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] The Third Year by Michael A. Aquino V°
structure_content.summary: This section details the Temple of Set's third year, marked by internal strife including the emotional breakdown and resignation of Executive Director Priest William F. Murray, and the schism led by Magister Robert Ethel, who formed the 'Order of the Inverse Pentagram.' Aquino analyzes these events as 'Seldon crises,' drawing parallels with the breakups of other magical orders like the Golden Dawn and the Church of Satan. He emphasizes the Temple's unique organizational structure with checks and balances, designed to prevent abuse and protect its philosophical integrity. The report also outlines future initiatives, including new publications (Crystal Tablet of Set, Ruby Tablet of Set revisions), enhanced communication (Scroll of Set index, Conclaves), and technological integration (electronic data-processing) to foster Setian growth and community.

Announces the unanimous appointment of Priestess Linda Thomas to a nine-year term on the Council of Nine, and the confirmation of Magister Ronald K. Barrett as Chairman of the Council of Nine for a term expiring June 30, XIV/1979.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Setian Elitism by Leon Marvell II°
structure_content.summary: This article addresses the concept of 'elitism' within the Temple of Set, clarifying that Setians are 'elite' not due to perceived superiority but by choosing a 'special vocation and direction in life' akin to a 'fine artist.' It asserts that the Temple's structure necessitates an elite order, focusing on those who are 'Elect' and willing to engage with complex Setian philosophy, while recognizing the inherent dangers of insular self-importance and advocating for mechanisms to negate these.

This administrative notice warns Setians about William F. Murray's continued efforts to spread misinformation and distrust regarding the Temple's leadership, despite compassionate arrangements made for him after his breakdown. It details a past incident of Murray's disruptive behavior at a Conclave and urges any Setian contacted by him to report the details to the Priesthood for factual clarification and support.

key_concepts.definition: A magical order founded on Setian philosophy, emphasizing the principle of Xeper and individual self-deification, distinct from the Church of Satan due to its rejection of LaVey's materialist and profit-driven approach.

The central magical principle of the Temple of Set, defined as 'self-creation' or 'becoming,' explained by the Will of Set. It signifies the process of an individual's conscious self-evolution and expansion of being.

The profound transformation and expansion of an individual's entire mode of existence, achieved through engagement with Setian principles and the process of Xeper, moving beyond natural or conventional limitations.

Individuals sought by Set, constituting a small percentage of humanity who possess the inherent qualities and intellectual capacity to understand and actualize the Setian path. The Temple aims to identify and nurture their potential.

A term borrowed from Asimov's Foundation trilogy, applied to critical episodes or internal conflicts within the Temple of Set that test the evolutionary stamina of the institution and its Initiates, leading to an 'evolutionary dialectic' and a more advanced state of existence rather than a return to status quo.

In the context of the Temple of Set, a Magus (such as Aquino V°) functions as an agency through which the magical principle of Xeper is defined and explained by the Will of Set, representing a higher intellectual presence.

A rival organization formed by Robert Ethel, characterized by Aquino as a 'social club for materialists' with proclaimed atheism and ceremonial pageantry, lacking the external authentication and philosophical depth of the Temple of Set.

practical_system.description: The Temple of Set's practical system, as described, is not a grimoire of specific rituals but an organizational and philosophical framework designed to facilitate the individual Setian's process of Xeper (self-creation) and Setamorphosis. It emphasizes a robust, counterbalanced governance structure (High Priest, Council of Nine, Executive Director) to prevent corruption and maintain the integrity of its teachings. The system fosters intellectual and magical development through open communication, shared resources (publications, conclaves), and a structured degree system, all within an environment intended to identify and support the 'Elect.'
tools: Organizational Structure: The system of checks and balances among the High Priest, Council of Nine, and Executive Director to distribute power and prevent misuse.
Publications: The Scroll of Set, Crystal Tablet of Set, and Ruby Tablet of Set serve as textual tools for conveying, debating, and evolving Setian philosophy.
Communication Channels: Inter-member communications, local/regional publications, and electronic data-processing are utilized to bridge distances and facilitate information exchange.

Degree System: While contested by some, it serves as a framework for discerning individual progress and drawing distinctions among Initiates, though its sanctity is reaffirmed as fundamental to the Temple's structure.
rituals: Conclaves: Regular gatherings (local, regional, and Temple-wide) for 'philosophical dialogue, magical workings, and personal relationships' essential for Setian development.

Publication Engagement: Active study and contribution to 'living works' like the Scroll of Set, Crystal Tablet of Set, and Ruby Tablet of Set, which define and expand Setian magical and philosophical doctrines.
Administrative Procedures: Orderly and systematic procedures for leadership replacement and dispute resolution, ensuring organizational stability.

relevant_quotes.text: The strength of the Æon which has now been unleashed lies in its promise to free the Elect among mankind once and for all from the great patterns of animalistic conceptualization and behavior in which they have been imprisoned for so many thousands of years: to take that realization of True Will as proclaimed by the Beast 666 and force it into an independent focus of identity and creative power through the principle of Xeper.

Why did something like this happen to the Temple? More importantly, what can we learn from it to prevent or at least minimize similar problems in the future? Dr. F.I. Regardie commented to me that schisms born of ego-inflation are an almost inescapable feature of magical orders.

If it remains true to its proclaimed atheism, then its priesthoods, rituals, and mysteries are just so much play-acting. But if it attempts to introduce any sort of external authentication into its practices, the O.I.P. betrays its origin as nothing more than a cold-blooded attempt to exploit Murray's illness, the climate of trust and open communication within the Temple of Set, and Ethel's high office in order to cripple and supplant the Temple with an authoritarian dictatorship.
And the power of a true Magus lies not in the tools of a Cæsar or a Napoleon but in a Word: Xeper.

The resolution of a Seldon crisis does not return everything to status quo. Rather it functions as a sort of evolutionary dialectic: The clash of a thesis (the pre-existing situation) and an antithesis (the crisis) results in a synthesis (a more advanced mode of existence).

critical_analysis.relevance: This document offers a critical internal perspective on the formative years of a modern magical order (Temple of Set), post-schism from the Church of Satan. It is highly relevant for understanding the practical challenges of establishing and sustaining an esoteric organization, particularly concerning leadership, internal dissent, and the integrity of its philosophical system. It highlights how organizational structure (checks and balances) and clearly defined core concepts (Xeper, Set) are crucial for the survival and evolution of such groups, providing a case study in institutional resilience and adaptation within the Left Hand Path tradition.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience includes Initiates and Priesthood of the Temple of Set, as an internal report and directive. Secondary audiences encompass scholars of new religious movements, occult studies, and organizational sociology, offering a unique firsthand account of conflict resolution and philosophical reaffirmation within a contemporary magical order. It is also of interest to practitioners of the Left Hand Path seeking insights into the historical development and operational challenges of prominent occult organizations.
